channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Smugglers in West Bank Open Door to Jobs in Israel, and Violence
item.media:description: Workers passing through a tunnel this month at a construction site in Israel that employs Palestinian laborers with and without permits.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: A thriving industry allows West Bank residents to get past what Israelis call a security barrier. It has a dangerous side effect: Attackers sneak through as well.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: Baghdad Journal: Falluja Restaurant Is Reborn in Baghdad, Offering Nostalgia With Its Kebab
item.media:description: A waiter at Haji Hussein with a stack of kebabs wrapped in bread as the day’s iftar meal got underway. The restaurant’s kebab is legendary in Iraq, as much for its quality as for its provenance.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Long before it became a haven for jihadists, the city of Falluja was known as the home of the Haji Hussein restaurant, where locals, soldiers, tourists and businessmen all ate.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Egyptian Court Nullifies Transfer of 2 Red Sea Islands to Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: People celebrated in Cairo on Tuesday after a court overturned an agreement to give the Tiran and Sanafir islands to Saudi Arabia.
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi had agreed to return Tiran and Sanafir during an April visit by the Saudi king, a move that set off protests.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Hoping Jobs for India Follow, Modi Clears Investors’ Path
item.media:description: A training room at a Flipkart, an e-commerce company in India, in August.
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.description: The changes are the most significant loosening of market restrictions since India began economic liberalization, with foreigners now permitted to own 100 percent of many companies.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: North Korean Defectors’ Detention Is Unlawful, Human Rights Lawyers Say
item.description: They accused the South’s spy agency of denying the 12 women access to legal services, and said that they had obtained power of attorney from the defectors’ families.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Chinese Court Says Environmental Agency Gave Polluter Lax Punishment
item.media:description: Chinese residents near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi last year. Rampant environmental degradation is of great concern to ordinary people across China.
item.description: The agency was accused of not acting forcefully enough against Qingshung Chemical Technology Company, which was found to have produced dyes without adequate safeguards.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Stay or Go? E.U. Referendum Divides British Families
item.media:description: Leslie Driscoll, right, argued with her daughter Louise at a cafe in London. Louise is the only one in her family who wants Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The vote this week over Britain’s membership in the European Union has prompted deep, sometimes bitter divisions, even between mothers and children.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Even Without Detonation, 4 Hydrogen Bombs From ’66 Scar Spanish Village
item.media:description: José Manuel González Navarro at a contaminated area near Palomares, Spain. He remembers the day 50 years ago when an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, dropping four hydrogen bombs.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Decades after an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, Palomares remains haunted by high radiation levels, a hurried cleanup, health fears and stigma.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A British Divorce From Europe? Henry VIII Blazed the Trail
item.media:description: A poster to remain in the European Union in London features a picture of Winston Churchill.
item.description: The country’s vote on leaving the European Union recalls in some ways England’s break five centuries ago with the papacy, another great power across the Channel.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Sentenced to 18 Years for War Crimes
item.media:description: Jean-Pierre Bemba, a former vice president of Congo, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Tuesday.
item.description: Mr. Bemba, a former vice president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, led a militia that committed crimes against humanity in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: C.D.C. and States Ponder Plans to Keep Ahead of Zika
item.media:description: Part of a mosquito-fighting effort in the Virgin Islands aimed at insects carrying the Zika virus.
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
item.description: The federal agency has been sketching out what it expects cities and states to need if a local case arises. That turns out to be a lot.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: I Sea, App That Claims It Can Find Migrants Adrift in Ocean, Is Called Misleading
item.media:description: A crowded inflatable boat with Syrian refugees drifted in the Aegean Sea between Turkey and Greece in August.
item.description: Developers say that the app is nothing but a marketing stunt because it showed users a static image of water, not real-time satellite photos of the ocean.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Sweden Toughens Rules for Refugees Seeking Asylum
item.media:description: A family from Iraq at a temporary home for asylum seekers of in Kladesholmen, Sweden, in February.
item.description: Sweden was once one of the most welcoming countries for refugees. Now its officials say they fear becoming overwhelmed.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Iranian General, Denouncing Move by Bahrain, Threatens ‘Bloody Intifada’
item.media:description: Bahraini demonstrators at a rally opposing the revocation of Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim’s citizenship in Diraz, west of Manama, on Monday.
item.description: Gen. Qassem Soleimani, the high-profile leader of the elite Quds Force of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, deplored the “mistreatment” of a leading Shiite opposition cleric.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Official Whose Arrest Stirred Protests Confesses to Taking Bribes
item.media:description: Villagers in Wukan carried Chinese flags as they marched in protest on Monday after the detention of a local leader, Lin Zuluan.
item.description: His wife said she believed the confession was forced, and it was unclear if it would have any effect in dispelling demonstrations in the fishing village of Wukan.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Palestinian, 15, Killed as Israeli Forces Sought to Halt Stone Throwing
item.description: One teenager died and four were wounded, and they appeared to be innocent bystanders who were hit while the military tried to halt Palestinians who were throwing stones and firebombs.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Car Bomb in Jordan, Near Syria Border, Kills 6
item.description: Four Jordanian soldiers, a police officer and a civil defense official died in the explosion, and 14 were wounded.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Bahrain’s Sunni Rulers Revoke Citizenship of Top Shiite Cleric
item.media:description: Shiite clerics in the village of Diraz, west of Manama, Bahrain, protested on Monday the revocation of the citizenship of a top cleric, Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim.
item.description: Critics said the move against the cleric, Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim, is likely to further inflame divisions in Bahrain, an important American ally.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Lightning Ridge Journal: An Amateur Undertaking in Australian Mining Town With No Funeral Home
item.media:description: Timbo Molyneux, left, his father, Ormie, right, and Ian Woodcock, all amateur undertakers, placed the coffin of Valerie Van Emmerik on the dance floor at a bowling club in Lightning Ridge, Australia, this month.
item.media:credit: Conor Ashleigh for The New York Times
item.description: In Lightning Ridge, the undertakers are all volunteers, bodies are stored in a beer fridge, funerals are held at a bowling club, and everyone gets a good send-off.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: The Interpreter: ‘Brexit’ Debate Has Voters Asking: What Does it Mean to be English?
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on whether to remain in the European Union, Robert Tombs, a historian, discusses a growing sense of English identity.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Russia Detains 5 in Deaths of 14 in Summer Camp Boat Accident
item.media:description: Emergency workers set out on Sunday to search for children missing after their canoes capsized Saturday in a sudden storm on Lake Syamozero in the Karelia region of Russia.
item.description: Camp instructors took the children out on a lake despite forecasts of storms, and investigators said some survivors spent hours in frigid water before being rescued.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Silence and Sobs as Parliament Honors Jo Cox, Slain British Lawmaker
item.media:description: Jo Cox, the member of Parliament who was killed on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Thomas Mair, the man charged with her murder, made a brief appearance in court via video link, as lawmakers paid tribute to their slain colleague.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Take a Number: The Rising Murder Count of Environmental Activists
item.media:description: A picture of Berta Cáceres placed at an altar during a demonstration outside Honduras’ embassy in Mexico City on June 15.
item.description: A new report by Global Witness puts last year’s death toll at 185, a sharp increase, with Brazil leading the way.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Trilobites: Saiga Population Grows After Mysterious Epidemic
item.media:description: A saiga mother and calf.
item.description: A recent census suggests the endangered antelopes in Kazakhstan are making modest gains after illness wiped out most of the species.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Virginia Raggi of Five Star Movement Sweeps Election for Rome’s Mayor
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, center, on Monday after winning the runoff vote. She will be Rome’s first female mayor, as well as its youngest at 37.
item.description: An anti-establishment candidate also won in Turin, in major blows to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his governing Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Protests Return to Wukan, Chinese Village That Once Expelled Its Officials
item.media:description: Lin Zuluan, the Communist Party secretary of the village of Wukan.
item.description: The protests called for the release of a detained local leader and the resolution of a long-simmering dispute over land sales, residents said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Indonesia Confirms Seizing Fishing Boat in South China Sea, Defying Beijing
item.description: The boat and its crew were taken Friday after warships fired warning shots at Chinese vessels suspected of illegal fishing, an Indonesian official said.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: The Interpreter: What Is ‘Brexit’? A Look at the Debate and Its Wider Meaning
item.media:description: Britain will decide on Thursday whether to leave the European Union, and voters are deeply split.
item.description: As British voters weigh whether to leave the European Union, they are wading into questions about national identity and Britain’s place in the world.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Bomb Kills Foreign Security Contractors in Kabul
item.description: At least 14 Nepalese and Indian guards were killed while riding in a minibus to work at the Canadian Embassy, police officials said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: What in the World: Dog Meat and Lychees: A Pairing Meant to Make You Feel Warm Inside
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photos by Eric Isselee and Eak Moto/shutterstock
item.description: At a festival in southern China that dog lovers condemn, the food pairing is all about energy, balance and fighting heat with heat.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: What in the World: How Many Die in a Typical Terror Attack? Fewer Than You Think
item.media:description: The sun rose behind 49 memorial crosses at a small lake near the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., last week.
item.description: Even so, what used to be symbolic acts have turned increasingly deadly, according to the Global Terrorism Database at the University of Maryland, which includes 140,000 attacks.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Magnet for Titanic Fans in an Unexpected Graveyard
item.media:description: The Fairview Lawn Cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on April 15, 2012, the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic.
item.description: Fairview Lawn Cemetery holds more victims of the world’s best-known shipwreck than any other place — including the grave of a certain J. Dawson.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Iran Says It Foiled One of the ‘Biggest Terrorism Plots Ever’
item.description: Several people were arrested over bombing attacks planned for June 16, and explosives were seized, the Intelligence Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Jo Cox and Britain’s Place in Europe
item.description: The “out” campaign countenanced the hatred that produced a political murder. Cox's legacy should be an open Britain in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Local Costs of the E.U. Refugee Deal
item.media:description: Migrants and refugees are stranded at the Greek port of Chios.
item.description: Greek villagers welcomed the migrants — until Athens got involved.
item.dc:creator: DAVID LEPESKA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Obama Needs to Protect the Iran Deal
item.description: Europe‘s banks still fear U.S. punishment if they enter Iran. Iranians ask if they’ve been betrayed. The president must rule out prosecution. Now.
item.dc:creator: SEYED HOSSEIN MOUSAVIAN and REZA NASRI

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
